Authors:
Fernando F Franco, Gislaine Angélica Rodrigues Silva,
Evandro Marsola Moraes, Cecilia Leiko Jojima, Nigel Paul Taylor, Daniela
Cristina Zappi, Marlon Camara Machado
Title:
PLIO-PLEISTOCENE DIVERSIFICATION OF Cereus Mill. (CACTACEAE,
CEREEAE) AND CLOSELY ALLIED GENERA
Journal: Botanical Journal of the Linnean Society
Keywords:
Cactus  Molecular Phylogeny  Biogeography  Divergence
estimates  PHYC  trnS-trnG
Abstract:
The genus Cereus (Cactaceae; Cereeae) comprises
approximately 30 predominantly South American species distributed among
four subgenera: Oblongicarpi, Ebneria, Mirabella and Cereus. To study
patterns of diversification in time and space, the trnS-trnG plastid
region was sequenced from representatives of Cereus and the closely
related genera Cipocereus and Praecereus. For a subset of our total
samples, we also obtained sequences of the low-copy nuclear gene
photoreceptor phytochrome C (PHYC). Phylogenetic analyses rendered the
genus Cereus as a paraphyletic taxon, indicating the genus Cipocereus as
a sister clade of the subgenus Mirabella. Moreover, with the exception
of Mirabella, the other subgenera of Cereus are also non-monophyletic.
The diversification of our ingroup lineage began around the
Plio-Pleistocene transition, and most species diversification events
occurred during the middle to late Pleistocene. Biogeographic analysis
determined the region of the Cerrado biome, in central Brazil, as the
most likely ancestral range of our ingroup. Furthermore, more recent
vicariance and dispersion events were identified for internal branches.
Overall, our results support the notion that both Neogene orogenic
events and Pleistocene climatic oscillations have contributed to shaping
the diversification of modern lineages of South American biota.
